item.title: From Poison to Plate: The Veggie Victory Story
item.itunes:title: From Poison to Plate: The Veggie Victory Story
item.description:
In this enlightening episode of Everyday's a Something, we delve into the fascinating history and modern significance of National Eat Your Vegetables Day, celebrated annually on June 17th. From its roots in early government nutrition campaigns to today's vibrant farmers' market culture, this episode explores how our relationship with vegetables has evolved over generations. Through vivid storytelling, we journey back to 1948, where a familiar scene of maternal persuasion sets the stage for examining how vegetable consumption has shaped American health consciousness. The episode highlights intriguing historical misconceptions, like European aristocrats' fear of tomatoes, while showcasing contemporary developments including innovative farmers' market demonstrations and the Council for Retirement Security's campaign linking vegetable consumption to healthy aging. Listeners will discover how this seemingly simple celebration has transformed into a platform for culinary exploration and nutritional education, encouraging everyone to expand their vegetable horizons and perhaps even venture into trying unfamiliar produce like kohlrabi or specialty eggplant varieties.
Further Reading: • "The History of Food in 100 Recipes - Book" (https://amazon.com/dp/0316229377) • "Food Fights: How History Has Shaped Our Meals - Book" (https://amazon.com/dp/1426220227) • "The Evolution of Farmers Markets in America" (https://smithsonianmag.com/food-history/farmers-markets) • "Vegetables: A Biography - Book" (https://amazon.com/dp/0226043487)

item.title: National Splurge Day: When Guilt-Free Shopping Made History
item.itunes:title: National Splurge Day: When Guilt-Free Shopping Made History
item.description:
Dive into the fascinating origin of National Splurge Day in this illuminating episode of Everyday's a Something. From its unexpected birth in 1994 by Chicago's "eventologist" Adrienne Sioux Koopersmith to its modern-day significance, discover how this unique holiday transformed America's relationship with guilt-free spending. The episode explores Koopersmith's revolutionary vision, emerging from her observation of Americans' puritanical approach to money during the post-recession era. Learn how the concept of a "splurge" has evolved from a modest $50 in 1994 to over $200 today, reflecting significant shifts in consumer behavior and economic perspectives. The narrative delves into how major retailers have embraced this celebration with "guilt-free" discounts, while financial advisors promote "strategic splurging" as a balanced approach to personal indulgence. This compelling exploration of consumer psychology, economic trends, and cultural evolution reveals how one woman's mission to normalize occasional treating has become a nationally recognized celebration of mindful indulgence.
Further Reading: • "The Psychology of Money" - Book (https://amazon.com/dp/0857197681) • "The History of Consumer Culture in America" (https://smithsonianmag.com/history/consumer-culture-america) • "The Joy of Spending: Why Treating Yourself Is Good for You" (https://psychologytoday.com/joy-of-spending) • "Mindful Money: The Art of Balanced Spending" - Book (https://amazon.com/dp/1541768736)
